SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He reports feeling fatigued and lightheaded for the past five weeks, as well as occasional bloating. He denies fever, chills, chest pain, and significant shortness of breath. He has been taking his medications and monitoring his blood pressure regularly.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Congestive Heart Failure
Hypertension

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Jugular Venous Distention: 8 cm
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally
• Lower Extremities: 1+ pitting edema

VITALS REVIEWED

Blood Pressure, Heart Rate, and Oxygenation: Within normal limits.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive Heart Failure:
• Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, likely due to heart failure.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Weigh daily and report weight gain or shortness of breath.
• Additional Testing: Order another echocardiogram.

Hypertension:
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure appears well-managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report elevated readings via patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain after a fall from a ladder while changing a light bulb yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She denies any other injuries.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Digoxin

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Atrial Fibrillation, Rhinoplasty

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stressing and knee flexion. Normal sensation.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a knee brace and crutches for the next couple of days. She will return in 1 week for re-evaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg every 6 hours with food, for a 2-week supply. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports that he was helping his daughter move heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, causing pain in his lower back. He heard a pop and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain subsided. The pain has been persistent since the incident, which occurred on Saturday.

The patient has been taking Tylenol and ibuprofen for the pain, as well as using Icy Hot. He reports some tingling in his right toes, which resolved by Sunday afternoon. He finds it difficult to find a comfortable sleeping position but notes that lying on his right side provides some relief.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to not monitoring his sugar intake well over the past few weeks due to a busy schedule. He has been taking metformin 500 mg twice daily. His blood pressure has been mostly under control, but he notes that it is not as well-regulated on weekends when he is out of the house.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

Back x-ray demonstrates normal bony alignment and no fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's history and physical exam findings are consistent with a lumbar strain from lifting heavy objects.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the affected area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8, indicating suboptimal control of his diabetes.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure readings have been running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been managing his knee osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Joint pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrew Perez is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for a kidney transplant, hypothyroidism, and arthritis. He presents today with complaints of joint pain.

The patient reports that over the weekend, he was moving boxes up and down the basement stairs. By the end of the day, his knees were very painful. The pain is equal in the bilateral knees. He states that he has had some knee problems in the past, but he believes that it was due to the repetition and the weight of the boxes. He states that the pain does not prevent him from doing his activities of daily living. By the end of the day on Saturday, his knee soreness interrupted his sleep. The patient has taken Tylenol and iced his knees for a short period of time, but nothing really seemed to help.

The patient states that he had a kidney transplant a few years ago for some polycystic kidneys. He notes that he saw Dr. Gutierrez a couple of weeks ago, and everything was normal at that time. The patient continues to utilize his immunosuppressant medications.

Regarding his hypothyroidism, the patient states that he is doing well. He has continued to utilize Synthroid regularly.

In regards to his arthritis, the patient states that occasionally he has pain in his elbow, but nothing out of the ordinary.

He denies any other symptoms such as fever, chills, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, and weight loss.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle pain. Endorses joint pain in the bilateral knees.
• Neurological: Denies headaches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: There is edema and erythema of the right knee with pain to palpation. Range of motion is decreased. Left knee exam is normal.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee is unremarkable. Good bony alignment. No acute fractures.

Labs: Within normal limits. White blood cell count is within normal limits. Kidney function is normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Andrew Perez is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for a kidney transplant, hypothyroidism, and arthritis. He presents today with complaints of joint pain.

Arthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports increased joint pain in his bilateral knees over the past weekend. Given that his right knee x-ray was unremarkable, I believe this is an acute exacerbation of his arthritis.
• Additional Testing: We will order an autoimmune panel for further evaluation.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours as needed.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to rest his knees. If his symptoms persist, we can consider further imaging and possibly a referral to physical therapy.

Hypothyroidism.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well on Synthroid and is asymptomatic at this time.
• Additional Testing: We will order a thyroid panel.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Synthroid.

Status post renal transplant.
• Medical Reasoning: He is doing well and has been compliant with his immunosuppressive medications. On recent labs, his white blood cell count was within a normal limits and his kidney function is stable.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female presenting with right finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over a mogul, her finger got caught and bent backward. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. The patient also reports a history of constipation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Constipation, managed with Miralax.
Appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Right index finger: Tenderness over the distal phalanx and pain with flexion. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint.

RESULTS

X-ray: No fractures identified. Everything lines up well.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 48-year-old female presenting with right finger pain after a skiing incident.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: Based on the patient's history, physical exam, and normal x-ray, the diagnosis is a contusion on the tip of the right index finger.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe an aluminum foam splint and Motrin 600 mg every six hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient should return for further evaluation.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient on the proper use of the splint and the importance of following the medication regimen.

Constipation.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is currently managing her constipation with Miralax.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management with Miralax.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bryan Smith is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for prior discectomy, who presents with back pain. The patient reports he felt something in the lower right side of his back while pushing a refrigerator up through another room. This happened about 5 days ago. The patient experiences pain while bending over. He has a history of a discectomy. He is worried that something happened. He has been taking ibuprofen, which has not been beneficial alone. With the combination of Tylenol and ibuprofen, he experiences symptomatic relief. He denies numbness and tingling in his legs, and any problems with his bladder or bowels.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematemesis, hematochezia, melena, heartburn, or abdominal pain.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary urgency, pain, or incontinence.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower right side back pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation to the right lumbar spine and the paraspinal muscles. Decreased flexion and extension of the back. Positive straight leg raise on the right. Strength is good bilaterally in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

X-ray of the lumbar spine is unremarkable. Normal bony alignment. No fractures were noted.

Labs: Within normal limits.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Bryan Smith is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for prior discectomy, who presents with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: He reports right-sided low back after moving a refrigerator approximately 5 days ago. X-ray of his lumbar spine is unremarkable. I do not believe this is related to his previous discectomy.
• Additional Testing: We will order a MRI of the lumbar spine for further evaluation.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily, as well as Ultram 50 mg every 4 hours as needed.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer him to physical therapy to be started after we get his MRI results back.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to discontinue the use of ibuprofen, but he may continue using Tylenol if he wishes.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion discovery.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with no significant past medical history, who presents with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches in the past. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention due to the discovery of a pituitary lesion during the workup for his headaches. The patient reports that the headaches are located behind his eyes and describe the pain as a dull, nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago, and has been worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient has not noticed any changes in vision or balance but has been bumping into door frames recently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss.
• Neurological: Endorses worsening headaches, denies numbness, tingling, or passing out.
• Ophthalmologic: Denies changes in vision or balance, but reports bumping into door frames.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
• Neurological: Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities.
• Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, are all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results being normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with worsening headaches and an incidental pituitary lesion discovery.

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression due to a pituitary adenoma.
• Additional Testing: Refer the patient for a visual field test and full eye exam.
• Surgical Treatment: Recommend transsphenoidal surgery to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa. Discuss the risks and benefits of the surgery with the patient.

Headaches.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's headaches are likely related to the pituitary adenoma and optic chiasmal compression.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Inform the patient that the surgery may help alleviate his headaches.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended surgical treatment plan.

Chief Complaint:

Right middle finger pain.

History of Present Illness:

Ms. Hill is a 41-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right middle finger pain after she was rear-ended in a motor vehicle accident. She has no other injuries.

Current Medications:

Digoxin

Past Medical History:

Atrial Fibrillation

Exam:

Examination of the right middle finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx.

Results:

X-rays of the right middle finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit show a comminuted distal phalanx fracture.

Impression:

Right middle finger distal phalanx fracture.

Plan:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a prescription for Tramadol 50 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain, dispense 8. She is provided a finger splint and will return in 2 weeks for a follow-up x-ray. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency room follow-up for chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Roger Nelson is a 62-year-old male who presents for emergency room follow-up for chest pain. The patient was doing yard work over the weekend when he began to feel short of breath and chest pain for approximately an hour. He denies a history of chest pain. The patient notes that after he finished, he felt fine. He has not had any other symptoms since that time. He denies a family history of heart disease.

The patient underwent right knee surgery a couple of months ago and has been feeling well since then. He has been in rehab and recovery. He denies chest pain while doing exercises in physical therapy for his knee.

His blood pressure was noted to be 180/95 mmHg when he visited the emergency room. He notes that his blood pressure has not been as high as usual.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: Carotid bruit on the right side.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.

RESULTS

Blood pressure is elevated.

EKG is normal.

Echocardiogram demonstrates decreased ejection fraction.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 62-year-old male who presents for emergency room follow-up. He presented to the emergency room for chest pain and elevated blood pressure of 180/95. His EKG from the emergency room was normal, but ejection fraction on echocardiogram was abnormal. His blood pressure today was still elevated.

Chest pain and hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Given his recent episode of blood pressure elevation and chest pain, I suspect an element of coronary artery disease as well as pumping dysfunction.
• Medical Treatment: We will change his blood pressure regimen to carvedilol 25 mg twice a day. He should also continue lisinopril 10 mg a day and I want to see how his blood pressure does on that regimen. I also recommended cardiac catheterization on him to make sure that he does not have any blockages in his heart.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a female patient who presents with a right wrist injury sustained yesterday morning while walking up and down the stairs doing laundry. She slipped and attempted to catch herself, resulting in immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist. The patient has not previously injured this arm. She rates the pain as a 9/10 in severity. She has tried ice, an ACE wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

PAST HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ibuprofen as needed for pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
Heart: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Lower legs: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
Upper extremities: Normal range of movement except for the right wrist. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Difficulty making a tight fist.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 140/70
Heart rate: 80 bpm
Respiratory rate: 20 bpm
Temperature: 97.2°F

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist injury with suspected Colles' fracture.

PLAN

1. X-ray confirmed a Colles' fracture with extra-articular involvement and ulnar styloid fracture.
2. Provide a brace for the patient's right wrist.
3. Schedule surgery for fracture repair.
4. Prescribe 50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours for pain management.
5. Begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery, with an assessment to determine frequency (estimated 3 times per week).
6. Follow-up appointment in one month to assess progress and discuss the patient's planned vacation.

INSTRUCTIONS

Wear the brace for six weeks. Attend physical therapy as recommended. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

Chief Complaint:

Right knee pain.

History of Present Illness:

Philip, a 56-year-old male, presents with right knee pain following a slip and fall accident while working on his property one week ago. He reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced pain and swelling since the incident. Pain is aggravated by flexing and extending the knee and is rated as 4-5/10 during movement. The patient has been taking ibuprofen for pain and swelling relief.

Past Medical History:

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg of Lisinopril.

Social History:

No tobacco or alcohol use.

Physical Exam:

Vitals: Blood pressure 150/70.

Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal: Right knee exam reveals pain to palpation of the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion. No pain on the lateral aspect of the knee.

Results:

X-ray of the right knee shows no fractures or bony abnormalities.

Assessment:

1. Right knee MCL strain.
2. Hypertension.

Plan:

1. For the right knee MCL strain, prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling relief. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day. Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg for hypertension management. Refer the patient to a nutritionist to improve diet and potentially reduce the need for medication in the future.

Instructions:

Schedule a follow-up appointment to assess the knee's healing progress and discuss any concerns regarding hypertension management.

CC:

Left shoulder pain.

HPI:

Mr. Wayne is a 59-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of left shoulder pain that he has been experiencing for about three weeks. He cannot recall any specific injury but has been active and doing work in his basement. He has had some aches and pains in the past but nothing that Tylenol could not take care of. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which takes the edge off but does not completely alleviate the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his arms or hands.

EXAM

Examination of the left shoulder shows limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, and no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips. Neurovascular exam of the left arm shows capillary refill less than three seconds and sensation intact to light touch.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder show no fractures.

IMPRESSION

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I will order an MRI for the left shoulder to further evaluate the issue. I am referring the patient to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for pain management. If symptoms do not improve, we can consider a steroid injection for the shoulder. The patient will follow up after completing physical therapy.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a 57-year-old female who presents with occasional left knee pain. She reports that the pain occurs less than once a day while walking and feels like her knee is giving out. The pain is located internally and involves the whole kneecap. She denies any popping sensation or history of injury to the knee. The pain is not severe enough to require medication and does not interfere with her daily activities. However, she is concerned about participating in line dancing during an upcoming trip due to the knee pain.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.
Diabetes mellitus.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys traveling and line dancing.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not mentioned.

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Metformin.
Farxiga.
Amlodipine.
Hydrochlorothiazide.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood pressure 122/70.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain: Suspect arthritis. Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.

2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.

3. Diabetes mellitus: Order hemoglobin A1C to assess the need for adjustments to metformin dosage. Order lipid panel.

The patient has no further questions. The nurse will schedule the echocardiogram.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, cough, and sore throat.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female who presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. Beverly reports a minimal cough and sore throat today, as well as mild fatigue. She denies any nausea or vomiting and has not experienced shortness of breath. The cough is described as a dry cough, and the sore throat has been persistent but fluctuating in severity. She has been trying to drink plenty of fluids to alleviate the symptoms. Beverly has been eating, but not as much as she normally would. She has a good support system from her family and nursing staff.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Stable, oxygen saturation within normal limits.

Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory: Crackles in lungs bilaterally.

Skin: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, likely related to radiation.

Lower extremities: No edema.

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
2. Radiation pneumonitis.
3. Painful swallowing.

PLAN

1. Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation therapy (45 Gy). Repeat imaging after completion of radiation therapy to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.
2. Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation related to radiation pneumonitis.
3. Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (four times daily) to alleviate painful swallowing and promote adequate food and fluid intake.

INSTRUCTIONS

Return to the clinic for the next scheduled visit.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Routine follow-up of chronic medical conditions.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Eugene Walker is a 61-year-old male who presents today for a routine follow-up of his chronic medical conditions. He reports increased fatigue, especially after long bike rides of 20-30 miles. He sleeps for 6-7 hours per night and believes he snores but denies any signs of apnea. He underwent an aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair on 01/22/2013 and has requested an echocardiogram. His last stress test was on 09/09/2019.

Mr. Walker has been noted to have pursed lips while walking and denies any wheezing. He has also noticed a 2-3 mm nodule in his right testicle, possibly with the epididymis, but is unsure. He has not had a vasectomy.

His current medication list includes clindamycin prior to dental procedures and vitamin D3 (50,000 IU on Sundays and 2000 IU the other 6 days).

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory: Pursed lip breathing noted. The exhalation phase is low. Lungs are clear to auscultation, no wheezing.

Genitourinary: No hernia noted. Left testicle normal.

RESULTS

Blood work from 04/10/2021 showed elevated alkaline phosphatase at 156, elevated total cholesterol of 247, HDL 66, LDL 166, and triglycerides 74. TSH was normal at 2.68. CBC was unremarkable. Vitamin D level was at the high end of normal at 94.

ASSESSMENT

1. History of aortic aneurysm repair.
2. Elevated alkaline phosphate level.
3. Lung field abnormal finding on examination.
4. Right testicular nodule.
5. Preventative health.

PLAN

1. History of aortic aneurysm repair: Order echocardiogram and stress test. Suggest follow-up with cardiology (Dr. Vincent Sanchez).
2. Elevated alkaline phosphate level: Order alkaline phosphatase and gamma GT.
3. Lung field abnormal finding on examination: Order pulmonary function testing for further evaluation.
4. Right testicular nodule: Referral placed to urology for possible ultrasound.
5. Preventative health: Perform MMR titer today. Recommend shingles vaccine next month. Patient is fully vaccinated for COVID-19.

INSTRUCTIONS

- Return in 1 year for routine wellness visit, sooner if needed.
- Call with any questions or concerns.

CC:

Right elbow pain.

HPI:

Mr. Lawrence is a 59-year-old male who presents today for an evaluation of right elbow pain. He reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery over the past week and started to develop pain in the inside of his right elbow. The pain has been present for four days and is rated as a 6/10 in intensity. The pain radiates slightly into his forearm but does not extend to his shoulder. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain has been interfering with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

EXAM:

Focused exam of the right elbow reveals moderate tenderness to palpation over the medial epicondyle. The patient has pain with pronation of the forearm and with resistance against flexion of the wrist. No pain with supination of the forearm. Vitals are stable.

RESULTS:

X-ray of the right elbow shows no fracture or bony abnormality.

IMPRESSION:

Medial epicondylitis (right elbow).

PLAN:

1. Rest: The patient is advised to wear a sling while awake and avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
2. Ice: Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Medication: Ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
4. Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to reassess the patient's condition.

The patient understands and agrees with the recommended treatment plan. The nurse will provide the patient with a sling and instructions for its use.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fall and chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient who presents after a recent fall and experiencing chest pain. He reports having shortness of breath but did not think much of it. He has a history of hypertension and is currently on Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc. He admits to not consistently taking his medications and having a poor diet, including salty foods such as chips.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.

Medications
Bumex, Cozaar, Norvasc.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Bumex 2 mg daily.
Cozaar 100 mg daily.
Norvasc 5 mg daily.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT

• Hypertension.
• Dietary indiscretion.
• Congestive heart failure.

PLAN

1. Hypertension: Continue Bumex 2 mg daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg daily. Encourage the patient to take medications consistently.

2. Dietary indiscretion: Consult with a nutritionist to provide dietary advice and support for the patient. Encourage the patient to monitor and improve their diet, focusing on reducing salt intake.

3. Congestive heart failure: Monitor weight daily and report any weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days. Continue current medications and follow up with a renal artery ultrasound to ensure no underlying issues are missed.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Take medications consistently.
2. Obtain a blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure at home.
3. Purchase a scale and weigh daily.
4. Attend a nutrition consultation.
5. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a 57-year-old male who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and severe, making it difficult for him to find a comfortable position. He reports dysuria and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief without success. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
History of kidney stones.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

No significant social history reported.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father: Kidney stones.

MEDICATIONS

Tylenol as needed for pain.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Positive for right-sided abdominal pain, dysuria, and dark-colored urine.
Negative for fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone): CT scan shows a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter without hydronephrosis.
   - Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
   - Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, alternating with Tylenol.
   - Provide a urine strainer to collect the stone for analysis.
   - Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
   - Follow up in 1-2 weeks; if symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

2. Dysuria: Likely related to the kidney stone. Monitor and reassess at follow-up appointment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 57-year-old male who presents with a nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on his right foot. The patient first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing a pair of tight shoes. The initial blister has since unroofed, revealing thick, soft, and mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient has been on antibiotics for six days, but the wound has turned black around the edges and he is experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. The patient also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is hot to touch. He has been coughing a lot in the past two days and has had difficulty catching his breath while walking around the house.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Diabetes mellitus with diabetic neuropathy.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient is a current smoker since his teens, actively trying to quit.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history.

MEDICATIONS

None reported.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythema. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
   - Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
   - Perform debridement in the office today.
   - Obtain a culture and consider different antibiotic therapy based on the results.
   - Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's calf.
   - Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.

2. Diabetes management.
   - Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist.
   - Continue monitoring hemoglobin A1C and blood sugars closely.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Richard is a pleasant patient who presents today with a tick bite on his right knee. He is unsure of when he got the bite but mentions spending time outdoors and in the woods. The bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. The patient denies any fever, chills, or joint pain other than his typical arthritic pain. He has not experienced any flu-like symptoms, cough, shortness of breath, or dizziness.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.
Diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Employed as an x-ray technician.
Enjoys spending time outdoors and hunting.

ALLERGIES

No known drug allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain.
• Endocrine: Diabetes.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional
Pleasant, healthy appearing, cooperative male in no distress.

Cardiovascular
Regular rate and rhythm.

Musculoskeletal
Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.

Skin
Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT

• Possible Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash on the right knee.
• Hypertension.
• Diabetes.

PLAN

1. For the tick bite and possible Lyme disease, start the patient on doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot tests to confirm the diagnosis. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and consider intravenous antibiotics if needed.
2. For hypertension, continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day. Order a lipid panel to monitor cholesterol levels.
3. For diabetes, order a hemoglobin A1C test and continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day. Monitor blood sugar levels and adjust treatment as needed. Order a basic metabolic panel to check kidney function.

The patient verbalizes understanding of the treatment plan and agrees. All questions were answered to the patient's satisfaction today.
